isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE - 1000 MODELS From 01/01/1998 to 02/07/2004 - BATTERY, CHARGING AND CRANKING SYSTEMS - DESCRIPTION

svcsubproc.title: Battery Power
svcsubproc.para: There are three main functions of the storage battery:

step1.para: To supply power to the starter and ignition system so the engine can be cranked and started.
To supply extra power required when the vehicle's load requirements exceed the supply from the charging system.
To act as a voltage stabilizer by smoothing out or reducing temporary high voltages within the electrical system.

svcsubproc.title: Charging System and Circuits
svcsubproc.para: The alternator is a generator which produces alternating current which is subsequently converted to direct current. The function of the alternator is to supply power to the vehicle electrical system. Any current above the needs of the vehicle components is used to charge the batteries.

svcsubproc.title: Cranking Motor System and Circuits
svcsubproc.para: The cranking motor provides the rotation of the engine crankshaft, through the flywheel. The cranking motor circuits provide power to the cranking motor to turn over the crankshaft of the engine. If all other systems are operational, the engine will start.

Components of the system consist of the crank motor and solenoid, the key start switch, crank inhibit relay, start relay, the Electronic Control Module (ECM), and a clutch switch with a manual transmission, or a neutral position switch with an automatic transmission.

svcsubproc.title: Cranking Motor System and Circuits - Cranking Motor Thermal Overcrank Protection
svcsubproc.para: On vehicles with thermal overcrank protection, excessive cranking will cause cranking motor temperature to reach a pre-set thermal overcrank limit. The thermal switch will then open causing the motor to disengage. When the crank motor cools, the switch closes, permitting the crank motor to operate again. The thermal switch interrupts the current to the cranking system start relay.
